title: Everardo Cristóbal
text:
José Everardo Cristóbal Quirino (born August 11, 1986 in Urandén, <a href="Michoac%C3%A1n">Michoacán</a>) is a Mexican <a href="canoe%20racing">sprint canoeist</a> who has been competing since 2005.
His first successful international performance was in 2006, when he won the silver medal in C-1 500 m and the gold medal in C-1 1000 m at the <a href="2006%20Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">2006 Central American and Caribbean Games</a>. Later the same year, at the <a href="2006%20ICF%20Canoe%20Sprint%20World%20Championships">world championships</a>, he surprisingly won the gold medal at C-1 1000 m, becoming the first Mexican to ever do this, and defeating race favorite and olympic medallist <a href="Andreas%20Dittmer">Andreas Dittmer</a>, who finished second. For such performance he received the "Premio Nacional del Deporte" (National Sports Award), which is awarded annually by the Mexican Sports Committee (<a href="http%3A//www.conade.gob.mx">"CONADE"</a> - in Spanish). In 2007, he won the gold medal both in C-1 500 m and C-1 1000 m at the <a href="2007%20Pan%20American%20Games">2007 Pan American Games</a>.
Cristóbal competed at the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a> in three events (<a href="Canoeing%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20C-1%201000%20metres">C-1 1000 m</a>, <a href="Canoeing%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20C-2%20500%20metres">C-2 500 m</a>, and <a href="Canoeing%20at%20the%202008%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20C-2%201000%20metres">C-2 1000 m</a>), but was eliminated in the semifinal round in each event. His best finish was sixth in the C-1 1000 m semifinal. At the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, he competed in two events, the C-1 200 m and the C-1 1000 m, finishing in 20th and 10th respectively.
